title.narrative: Multi-sectoral Mitigation of high-risk EVD outbreak in Uganda

description.narrative: The main objective of this UNICEF project is to enhance Uganda’s capacity to prevent, detect and effectively respond to Ebola Virus Disease spread from DRC to Uganda in five targeted districts. With this CERF fund, UNICEF will reach the targeted population with key EVD prevention messages through interpersonal communication and will improve WASH facilities in four health facilities to strengthen infection prevention and control. the project will last six months and will benefit 355,000 people including 102,441 girls.

title.narrative: Réponse multisectorielle d’urgence pour contribuer à l’interruption de la maladie à virus Ebola dans les Provinces du Nord Kivu et de l’Ituri

description.narrative: The main objective of this UNICEF project is to contribute to the reduction of mortality and morbidity of people affected by the Ebola outbreak. With this CERF grant, UNICEF will procure and distribute 72,000 bags of ready-to-use infant milk, decontaminate 100 Ebola-infected patient houses, and equip four public nurseries. The project will last six months and will benefit 429,411 people including 38,988 women; 223,294 girls; and 5,760 persons living with disabilities.

title.narrative: Implementation of the Ebola Prevention, Preparedness and Response Plan for Congolese (DRC) Refugees in Burundi

description.narrative: The main objective of this UNHCR project is to mitigate and minimise risks of an Ebola outbreak within the population of refugees and other people in Burundi. With this CERF grant, UNHCR will provide 90 handwashing facilities, install three isolation rooms and will distribute 7,000 IEC materials in three refugee camps. The project will last three months and will directly target 29,788 Congolese refugees and indirectly benefit 3 million host community members.

title.narrative: Targeted Ebola preparedness activities in Refugee hosting districts

description.narrative: The main objective of this UNHCR project is to strengthen Infection Prevention and Control (IPC) at the refugees' settlements and high-volume health facilities in Kisoro, Kanungu and Kyegegwa. With this CERF grant, UNHCR will procure and distribute Personal Protective Equipment and supplies for a value of $160,000. UNHCR will also construct screening shelters at Bunagana, Nteko, Busanza and Ishasha Points of Entry. the project will last six months and will benefit 1,476,509 people including 737,603 women and girls.

title.narrative: Assessing Population Mobility Dynamics and Patterns To Strengthen the Ebola Virus Disease Readiness Activities In Burundi

description.narrative: The main objective of this IOM project is to contribute to the prevention and detection of an eventual EVD outbreak, through improving access to data on population mobility mapping information. With this CERF grant, IOM will conduct district level population mobility mapping (PMM) around selected priority health districts to inform public health interventions through four reports. The project will last six months and will benefit 89,695 people.

title.narrative: Improving national preparedness and information management for Ebola virus disease surveillance at Ugandan points of entry

description.narrative: The main objective of this IOM project is to enhance the Governement of Uganda capacity to prevent, detect and control the outbreak of Ebola virus disease (EVD) and other health risks at the border. With this CERF grant, IOM will train 124 BorderAgency ficers on Health, Border & Mobility Management. IOM will also procure and distribute 90 Infection and Prevention Control kits. The project will last six months and will benefit 6,633 people including 3,380 women and girls.

title.narrative: Réponse à l’épidémie de la maladie à Virus Ebola dans les provinces du Nord-Kivu et de l''Ituri

description.narrative: The main objective of this IOM project is to contribute to the interruption of the chain of transmission of Ebola Virus Disease in North Kivu and Ituri. With this CERF grant, IOM will procure and distribute WASH supplies and rehabilitate 100 screening sites at different points of entry in DRC. The project will last six months and will benefit 45,000,000 people (mainly the ones crossing the border) including 20,175,750 women and 1,874,250 girls.

title.narrative: Dedicated UNHAS air support for the Ebola Virus Disease readiness in South Sudan .

description.narrative: The main objective of this WFP project is to provide logistical support to State Level coordination units with multiple interagency missions from the national EVD coordination task force. With this CERF grant, WFP will contract one fixed wing aircraft to facilitate the transportation of supplies from Juba to prioritized field locations, allow timely access to the field to the partners and facilitate quick transfer of EVD samples from the field to Juba if the EVD spread to South Sudan. The project will last three months and will benefit the HCT (including the Government entities intervening in the prepardness activties).

title.narrative: Ebola preparedness, logistic support in six priority provinces in Burundi

description.narrative: The main objective of this WFP project is to put in place EVD logistics preparedness in Burundi. With this CERF grant, WFP will equip 14 points of entry in Burundi with semi-temporary screening structures and semi-temporary isolation structures. To do so WFP will procure and install 14 tents and 13 containers for the total of US$71,000. WFP will hire a EVD Logistic Specialist to roll out the activities. The project will last six months.

title.narrative: Enhancing Ebola prevention and response preparedness through logistics support.

description.narrative: The main objective of this WFP project is to scale-up the logistics and supply chain capacity of the Government of Uganda and humanitarian actors in response to the high risk of Ebola crossing into Uganda from DRC. With this CERF grant, WFP will establish a storage facility dedicated to the Ministry of Health for EVD preparedness and response supplies and equipment. Under the coordination of WHO, WFP will also provide engineering, construction and logistics support to the partners. The project will last six months.

title.narrative: Enhancing Ebola readiness and response capacity through coordinated and scalable regional inter-agency common logistics services facilitated by staging area in Entebbe/Kampala

description.narrative: The main objective of this WFP project is to provide Common Logistics Services in support of UN agencies, NGOs and national governments engaged in regional Ebola Preparedness and Response. With this CERF grant, WFP will establish a Turnkey base camp of a value of $200,000 in Uganda to support the potential logistics needs of Uganda, Rwanda, South Sudan, Burundi and DRC for an Ebola response. The project will last three months.

title.narrative: Rwanda Ebola Virus Disease Readiness Project

description.narrative: The main objective of this WHO project is to enhance operational readiness capacities for EVD detection, response and containment in Rwanda. With this CERF grant, WHO will train 20,000 community health workers on surveillance and case tracking among other topics. WHO will also procure two thermo-scanners for $100,000 and install them at two of the busiest and high-risk point of entries. The project will last six months and will benefit 5,319,625.

title.narrative: Strengthening Ebola Virus Disease Operational Readiness and Preparedness in Burundi.

description.narrative: The main objective of this WHO project is to enhance Burundi’s capacity to efficiently prevent, early detect, and effectively manage the spread of an Ebola Virus Disease outbreak from DRC. With this CERF grant, WHO will supply 12 District Hospitals with kits and equipment to manage EVD cases and safe burials. WHO will also train 48 clinical staffs on EVD case management and infection prevention & control. The project will last six months and will benefit 2,870,256 people including 1,460,960 women and girls and 1,409,296 men and boys.

title.narrative: Strengthening Country Readiness to Respond to the Imminent Spill-over of Ebola Virus Disease into Uganda from the DRC

description.narrative: The main objective this WHO project is to contribute to the country readiness to respond to a potential spill-over of the Ebola Virus Disease into Uganda from the DRC. With this CERF grant, WHO will procure and distribute IPC equipments for a value of $86,872. WHO will also procure and install four incinerators in health facilities and secure lined organic waste pits in 30 locations. The project will last six months and will benefit 1,463,500 people including 760,700 women and girls.

title.narrative: Renforcer la résilience des communautés pour pérenniser les acquis au-delà de la riposte à la 10eme épidémie d’Ebola en RDC.

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving nutrition, WASH, shelter and essential household item, education and child protection assistance to vulnerable communities in Ituri, Nord Kivu and Sud Kivu. This UNICEF project converts facilities developed during the Ebola crisis into community homes to help monitor Ebola survivors and prevent a resurgence of the disease; provides psycho-social to orphans of Ebola; ensure follow-up home visits for children under 24 months of age receiving breast-milk substitutes; treats severe acute malnutrition; trains community health workers; constructs boreholes to provide communities and schools with access to fresh water; distributes WASH kits; provides psycho-social support to children and school teachers; distributes kits containing essential household items; and conducts awareness-raising. The nutrition component of the project provides life-saving assistance to 149,799 people, including 2,568 women, 71,001 boys and 73,906 girls. The WASH component of the project provides life-saving assistance to 110,273 people, including 22,936 women, 31,759 boys and 34,406 girls. The shelter/NFI component of the project provides life-saving assistance to 57,500 people, including 12,075 women, 17,250 boys and 16,675 girls. The education component of the project provides life-saving assistance to 31,400 people, including 703 women, 15,000 boys and 15,000 girls. The child protection component of the project provides life-saving assistance to 10,293 people, including 1,047 women, 4,088 boys and 4,976 girls. Exceptionally this project will be implemented over the course of 18 months.

title.narrative: Appui à la transition post- Ebola pour les populations des zones affectées à travers les services de santé reproductive et la protection (VBG et PEAS)

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving sexual and reproductive health assistance and protection assistance focused on sexual- and gender-based violence to IDPs, returnees and host community members in Ituri and Nord-Kivu. This UNFPA project provides maternal and neonatal health care services, raises awareness about family planning and the transmission of sexually-transmitted diseases (including Ebola), supports survivors of sexual- and gender-based violence through cash transfers, distributes dignity kits, raises awareness about preventing sexual exploitation and abuse. The health component of the project provides life-saving assistance to 26,450 people, including 5,580 women, 7,856 boys and 7,610 girls. The SGBV-protection component of the project provides life-saving assistance to 25,742 people, including 10,691 women, 7,646 boys and 7,405 girls.

title.narrative: Renforcement de l’environnement de la Protection pour les PDIs et Communautés hôtes dans les provinces du Nord Kivu, Sud Kivu et Ituri en RDC affectées par la Maladie à Virus Ebola et les conflits.

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving protection, WASH and education assistance to host communities, IDPs and returnees in the provinces of Ituri, North-Kivu and South-Kivu. This UNHCR project works with communities to identify protection needs, conducts protection monitoring, contributes to the registration of IDPs, supports community-based conflict resolution, strengthens systems to prevent sexual- and gender-based violence, constructs boreholes to provide communities access to safe drinking water, distributes hygiene kits, constructs family latrines and showers, supports access to primary education, and provides psycho-social support to children. The protection component of the project provides life-saving assistance to 732,245 people, including 234,318 women, 175,739 boys and 205,028 girls. The WASH component provides life-saving assistance to 25,000, including 5,457 women, 7,224 boys and 7,393 girls. The education component provides life-saving assistance to 5,309 people, including 900 women, 1,520 boys and 2,280 girls. Exceptionally this project will be implemented over the course of 18 months.

title.narrative: Assistance humanitaire multisectorielle pour les populations vulnérables affectées par l’épidémie de la Maladie à Virus Ebola et les mouvements de populations dans l’Est de la RDC

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving health, shelter and WASH assistance to vulnerable communities in Ituri, Nord Kivu and Sud Kivu. This IOM project equips border crossings and points of entry with the tools needed to detect early warning signs of any flare-ups of the Ebola virus and other diseases; raises awareness about infection prevention and control; provides cash transfers 4,500 families currently living with host community members to help them rebuild their homes; constructs boreholes to give communities access to fresh water; and installs hand-washing stations in schools. The health component of this project provides life-saving assistance to 1,005,375 people including 435,098 women, 216,987 boys and 117,636 girls. The shelter and essential household items component of this project provides life-saving assistance to 41,840 people, including 11,715 women, 10,460 boys and 11,297 girls. The WASH component of this project provides life-saving assistance to 16,000 people, including 4,480 women, 4,000 boys and 4,320 girls. Exceptionally this project will be implemented over the course of 12 months.

title.narrative: Assistance alimentaire en faveur des survivants de la Maladie à Virus Ebola et les communautés affectées dans les provinces du Nord & Sud Kivu et de l’Ituri.

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving food security, nutrition and education assistance to IDPs, returnees and host community members in Ituri, Nord Kivu and Sud Kivu. This WFP project provides food assistance in the form of cash transfers, initially through unconditional transfers to 87,000 people including Ebola-survivors for a period of 6 periods, followed by conditional transfers (in coordination with FAO's CERF-funded project) to roughly a third of these individuals for a period of 3-6 months. Additionally this project provides nutritional assistance to Ebola survivors and their households in order to support treatment, recovery and rehabilitation from the disease; provides meals (in coordination with UNICEF's CERF-funded project) to 9,000 children in schools in Ebola-affected areas to promote enrollment and attendance; screens children aged 6-23 months as well as pregnant and nursing women for acute malnutrition; and raises awareness about proper nutritional practices. The food security component of this project provides life-saving assistance to 87,000 people, including 20,800 women, 22,500 boys and 24,400 girls. The education component provides life-saving assistance to 9,300 people including 126 women, 4,300 boys and 4,700 girls. The education component of this project provides life-saving assistance to 3,640 people, including 776 women, 1,031 boys and 1,117 girls. Exceptionally this project will be implemented over the course of 18 months.

title.narrative: Maintien de Zéro cas d’Ebola et Offre des Soins aux Survivants et aux Communautés Affectées par l’Epidémie d’Ebola

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving health assistance to vulnerable communities in Ituri, North-Kivu and South-Kivu. This WHO project supports and monitors Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) survivors, procures essential medical equipment for 5 general reference hospitals, conducts contact tracing in the event new cases are identified, trains health workers on integrated disease surveillance and response, establishes community-based disease surveillance and provides access to essential life-saving healthcare services. The project provides life-saving assistance to 403,000 people including 109,000 women, 93,000 boys and 100,000 girls. Exceptionally this project will be implemented over the course of 9 months.

title.narrative: Réponse multisectorielle d’urgence pour contribuer à l’interruption de la maladie à virus Ebola en Guinée

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving health, water & sanitation, protection and education assistance to communities affected by the Ebola Virus Disease in the Nzérékoré region and surrounding areas. This UNICEF project; procures personnel protective equipment for healthcare workers; supports the roll-out of an Ebola vaccination campaign; provides healthcare to children; raises awareness about infection prevention and control measures including through targeted support to teachers and students; provides nutritional care to infants separated from their mothers to avoid contamination through breastfeeding; promotes access to clean water; delivers psychosocial care to Ebola survivors; distributes cash assistance to families affected by the disease; and raises awareness about gender-based violence and sexual exploitation and abuse. The health component of the project provides assistance to 249,000 people, including 100,000 women, 100,000 men and 49,000 children. The water, sanitation and hygiene component provides assistance to 105,000 people. The education component provides assistance to 84,000 students and teachers. The protection component provides assistance to 55,000 people including 33,000 children. The nutrition component to 5,600 women and infants.

The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving health assistance to vulnerable communities at risk of spread of EVD outside Guinea. This UNICEF project will provide support for coordination, capacity building of first line responders, increased knowledge and empowerment of the communities and distribution of critical supplies. UNICEF will help to scale up Health, risk communication and community engagement (RCCE), Infection Prevention and Control (IPC)/WASH, and psychosocial care interventions at the community, school and healthcare facility levels to prevent the spread of Ebola Virus Disease. The project provides life-saving assistance people, including 2,047,804 women, 1,748,024 men and 4,355,778 children.

title.narrative: Provision of life-saving interventions in Ebola pandemic response in North Kivu province, Democratic Republic of the Congo

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving health, water, sanitation, and protection assistance to vulnerable communities in regions affected by, and those at risk of, Ebola. This UNICEF project raises awareness about infection prevention and control measures; improves water, hygiene and sanitation in health facilities; provides psychosocial support to Ebola patients and their families and to healthcare workers; continues to provide access to basic essential services for gender-based violence and the prevention of sexual exploitation and abuse. The water, sanitation and hygiene component of the project provides life-saving assistance to 8,400 people, including 1,764 women, 1,680 men, 5,000 children, and 250 people with disabilities. The protection component of the project provides life-saving assistance to 7,100 people, including 1,350 women, 1,200 men, 4,500 children, and 220 people with disabilities. The health component of the project provides life-saving assistance to 3,900 people, including 590 women, 1,370 men, 1,900 children.

title.narrative: Reduction of Ebola disease transmission in affected areas through the strengthening of SRH health services and protection against sexual exploitation and abuse in Katwa, Butembo, Biena and Musienene

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving sexual and reproductive health assistance and gender-based violence protection assistance to vulnerable communities in regions affected by, and those at risk of, Ebola. This UNFPA project procures hand-washing kits and infection prevention and control kits for 7 maternity wards; conducts refresher trainings for midwives on obstetric and neonatal care of suspected and confirmed Ebola patients; raises awareness about the infection prevention and control measures in local communities; supports the network for the prevention of sexual exploitation and abuse; and provides referral services for survivors of gender-based violence. The health component of the project provides life-saving assistance to 32,000 people, including 6,300 women, 6,100 men, 19,000 children, and 1,500 people with disabilities. The protection component of the project provides life-saving assistance to 20,000 people, including 4,200 women, 4,100 men, 11,700 children, and 1,000 people with disabilities.

title.narrative: Réponse à l’épidémie de la maladie à Virus Ebola dans la région de Nzérékoré

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving health assistance to communities affected by the Ebola Virus Disease in the Nzérékoré region. This IOM project strengthens the capacities of 10 points of entry and 9 points of control to detect, report, and isolate suspected cases of Ebola; supports contact tracing efforts; and procures personnel protective equipment as well as handwashing stations to limit the spread of the disease. The project provides life-saving assistance to 486,000 people, including 102,000 women, 120,000 men, 264,000 children.

title.narrative: Active surveillance among travelers and mobile populations in Ebola Virus Disease outbreak in North Kivu, Eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving health to vulnerable communities in regions affected by, and those at risk of, Ebola. This IOM project activates health screening points with hand-washing stations at strategic locations in the affected health zones, conducts contact tracking of known contacts with infected persons, and raises awareness and infection prevention and control measures. The project provides life-saving assistance to 595,000 people, including 121,000 women, 114,000 men, 360,000 children, and 105,000 people with disabilities.

title.narrative: Appui à la riposte MVE à travers de services aériens et d’assistance alimentaire

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving food assistance and to facilitate the transport of humanitarian personnel and cargo. On the one hand, WFP provides food security to households in the N'Zérékoré region to support WHO’s efforts to contain the Ebola Virus Disease through contact tracing. This approach builds on the best practices during the 2014-16 West African Ebola outbreak. On the other hand, the funding supports the operation of UN Humanitarian Air Service (UNHAS) flights between Conakry and N'Zérékoré. The project provides life-saving food security assistance to 16,500 people, including 4,400 women, 3,800 men, 8,200 children.

title.narrative: Projet de Riposte à l’ Epidémie de Maladie à Virus Ebola (MVE) en Guinée

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving health assistance in the N’Zérékoré region. This WHO project puts in place infection prevention and control measures, strengthens contacting tracing efforts, supports a vaccination campaign, boosts laboratory capacities to process specimens from suspected case in a timely manner, raises awareness about the spread of the disease, procures personnel protective equipment for healthcare workers, and provides treatment and psycho-social support to patients and their families. The project provides life-saving health assistance to 195,000 people, including 73,000 women, 72,000 men and 50,000 children.

title.narrative: West Africa Ebola Virus Disease Readiness project

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving health assistance to vulnerable communities at risk of spread of Ebola virus disease in Sierra Leone, Liberia, Cote D'Ivoire, Mali, Senegal and Guinea-Bissau. This WHO project will support operations of the Public Health Emergency Operation Centre’s to curtail the EVD outbreak at national and subnational level, conduct Ebola virus disease surveillance, scale-up EVD prevention efforts at Points of Entry and provide technical support for Ebola virus disease laboratory diagnosis and case management. The project provides life-saving assistance to 33,139,174 people, including 8,410,699 women, men and 16,839,083 children and 2,752 people with disabilities in health sector.

title.narrative: Rapid response to the Ebola virus disease (EVD) outbreack in Nord Kivu province in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving health assistance to vulnerable communities in regions affected by, and those at risk of, Ebola. This WHO project supports early detection, contact training, and active search of Ebola Virus Disease cases; improving infection prevention and control measures in health facilities; and providing medical care for Ebola patients. The project provides life-saving assistance to 187,750 people, including 50,690 women, 46,330 men, 90,120 children, and 28,000 people with disabilities.
